awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Technology-Enhanced Statistics Learning Software App
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in the development of an immersive, game-based, learning app to help teach statistics in an engaging way to middle and high school students.  Designed as a classroom resource, the app is aimed at providing a mechanism to promote statistical thinking. The app will integrate research activities into the teaching of statistical concepts and techniques to common core curriculum standards. The game design is expected to increase interest in statistics and also increasing the number of students going into STEM related fields.  

This game-based app features artificial intelligence (AI) and augmented reality learning components tailored to meet students where they are academically and customize fit to each student’s individual interests. This app will be used as a classroom resource. Phase I research and development addresses technical feasibility hurdles such as the development of augmented reality and artificial intelligence features. Other challenges include the development of a user-friendly, seamless application that does not require internet access and a feasible system architecture to integrate the computational engine with the game user interface and ensure reasonable response times. To overcome the inherent technical hurdles, the team will use an agile development cycle that allows for faster development of the finished product, as well as flexibility to respond to changes and requirement updates as they occur.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of our Phase I SBIR project was the development of a proof-of-concept prototype for 6th grade learning software that teaches core concepts in Statistics and Probability. The software was designed to promote math literacy by leveraging interactive and gamified learning techniques, increase student engagement, facilitate independent learning, and increase exam scores in Statistics making it a must-have for parents of middle school students. 

During Phase I R&D, our primary objective was to establish both the technical feasibility and commercial viability of 6th-grade statistics learning. This phase sought to demonstrate that the software could deliver an engaging, accessible, and customizable learning experience, specifically tailored to the needs of middle school students. While the full model of the software will have several innovative features, Phase I goals were concentrated in three primary areas including gamification and personalized learning.

The project initially aimed to develop a mobile app, but technical constraints, customer discovery (during the Beat-The-Odds Bootcamp), and accessibility considerations led to the decision to shift towards a PC game model. This transition allowed for more robust functionality and alignment with learning hardware commonly used by students.

Customer Discovery (Bootcamp / I-Corps): To ensure the platform’s educational efficacy, the team conducted over 130 interviews with parents, educators, school administrators, and other stakeholders. These conversations were instrumental in identifying the needs and preferences of teachers, parents, and students regarding digital learning tools. Educators and parents shared insights into the current challenges of teaching statistics / statistical learning and expressed the need for a resource that could cater to diverse learning styles and technological abilities.

Prototype Development and Testing: Beta testing with a select group of 6th grade students was conducted bi-monthly and feedback was used to help shape the prototype’s overall development. Utilizing an agile development approach, the project team iteratively developed and tested the software’s core features. This methodology enabled the team to incorporate feedback from user focus groups in real-time, refining the design based on practical needs and preferences. Early testing focused on optimizing the user interface, avatar interaction, and personalized learning. Throughout this process, we maintained an emphasis on creating an intuitive and visually appealing interface, which is crucial for engaging middle school students.

The achievements of Phase I demonstrate the software’s potential to bridge educational gaps and support independent learning through innovative technology. As Phase II progresses, the focus will be on building upon this foundation by, enhancing adaptive learning algorithms, improving scalability, and broadening market reach. With these efforts, the software will not only offer a more comprehensive and personalized learning experience but also position itself as a valuable tool for educators and parents alike. By addressing both technical and commercial objectives, Phase II will further solidify the software’s role in the EdTech market, providing students with the resources they need to succeed in a data-driven world.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Zaneta Chapman
